titleStmt.title: William Warden v. O. D. Butterfield. Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus

bibl.title: William Warden v. O. D. Butterfield. Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p:
Territory of Washington, County of King ss In the district court holding terms at Seattle.
In the matter of the application of, Wm. Warden for a rit of Habeas Corpus.
To the Hon. C. H. Hanford Judge of the District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington Territory:

Your petitioner William Warden respectfully shows, that he is unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of his liberty by O. H. Butterfield Cheif of Police and James Bogart and other officers of said jail whose names are unknow to this affiant at the City Jail im the City of Seattle in the County of King and Territory of Washington:

That the said detention, imprisonment confinement and restraint are illegal; and that the illegality thereof consists of this to-wit: That your petitioner is charged with no offence
agaisnt the laws of Washingtin Territory of the ordinances or law of the City of Seattle and is detained and restrained of his liberty without any warrant or proper process of law; that the only pretext or cause of such arrest and detention is by virtue of a certain telegram a copy of which is aas follows to-wit: O. D. Butterfield, Cheif of Police Seattle W. T.
We will send for Ross if you have him. Reward $50. Will pay for his detention until we can send a guard for him.. Will forward photo by mail and description. Answer. Aull Will Warden,

Wherefore, your petitioner prays that a writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted, directed to the said O. D. Butterfield and James Bogart commanding them to have the body of Wm. Warden before your honor forthwith to do and receive what shall and there be considered by your honor concerning him in his behalf and that your petitioner may be restored to his liberty. Dated May 25th. 1889. William Warden

Territory of Washington x x ss County of King x William Warden being duly sworn deposes and says: That he is the petitioner named in the foregoing petition subscribed by him, that he has heard the foregoing petition read, and knows the contents thereof and that the statements therein made he beleives to be true. William Warden Subscribed and sworn to before me this 25th. day of May 1889? L H Wheeler Notary Public in and for Wash. Ter.
